questions.text: A patient presented with a painless hard nodule in the neck. On Examination it is not warm to touch and is easily mobile. Biopsy was taken and on anaerobic culture, molar was taken and on anaerobic culture, molar tooth colonies grew in 2-3 days which showed gram-positive branching rods on staining. Which of the following is the drug of choice in this condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Penicillin This is a case of cervical actinomycosis and the drug of choice is Penicillin. Actinomyces: filamentous organism. An anaerobe, mostly non-acid fast. Oral actinomycosis has a triad of: Sinus. Swelling. Sulphur granules. Most common site – cervicofacial When sulphur granules crush and see them under microscope there is sun ray appearance. Drug of choice: Penicillin.

Solution:

Somatic Hypermutation Somatic Hypermutation is a process in which point mutations accumulate in the antibody V-regions of both the heavy and light chains, at rates that are about 106-fold higher than the background mutation rates observed in other genes. Cells that emerge will have a stronger and more specific response to the antigen - and this is called affinity maturation. VDJ recombination is the process by which T cells and B cells randomly assemble different gene segments – known as variable (V), diversity (D) and joining (J) genes – in order to generate unique receptors (known as antigen receptors) that can collectively recognize many different types of molecule. During the process of splicing, introns are removed from the pre- mRNA by the spliceosome and exons are spliced back together. If the introns are not removed, the RNA would be translated into a nonfunctional protein. Splicing occurs in the nucleus before the RNA migrates to the cytoplasm. Immunoglobulin class switching is a biological mechanism that changes a B cell's production of antibody from one class to another; for example, from an isotype called IgM to an isotype called IgG

questions.text: Match the following E. coli with its pathogenesis / Virulence (Column – (A) with Column – (B): Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A1, B2, C3, D4 ETEC : Most common cause of traveler's diarrhea. It causes acute watery diarrhea in infants and adults. Common serotypes associated are: O6, O8, O15, O25, O27, O153, O159, etc. It is toxigenic but not invasive. . Pathogenesis: Attachment to intestinal mucosa is mediated by CFA (Colonization Factor Ag). . Toxins: Heat labile toxin or LT (increased cAMP). Heat stable toxin or ST (increased cGMP). Enteropathogenic E. coli (EPEC) : EPEC frequently cause infantile diarrhea (outbreaks) and rarely sporadic diarrhea in adults. It is non toxigenic and noninvasive. Mechanism of diarrhea: Adhesion to intestinal mucosa, mediated by plasmid coded bundle-forming pili. A/E lesions (attaching and effacing lesions) on the intestinal epithelium. Enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC) : O157: H7 (most common serotype). EHEC is usually transmitted by contaminated food, i.e. lettuce, spinach, sprouts and undercooked ground beef. Low infective dose (< 102 CFU) of EHEC can also initiate the infection. Pathogenesis: EHEC secretes a toxin called verocytotoxin or Shiga-like toxin Causes: HC (hemorrhagic colitis):Manifests as gross bloody diarrhea, abdominal pain and fecal leukocytosis but no fever. Hemorrhagic uremic syndrome (HUS): bloody diarrhea, thrombocytopenia, renal failure and encephalopathy but without fever. Diagnosis: Sorbitol MacConkey agar: EHEC in contrast to other E.coli, does not ferment sorbitol. Toxin detection: Cytotoxicity in Vero cell lines (gold standard method). Fecal toxin antigen detection by ELISA or rapid tests. PCR can be used to detect gene coding for VT. Entero invasive E. coli (EIEC): Pathogenesis: EIEC is not toxigenic but invasive by nature (Unique Feature) . The epithelial cell invasion is mediated by a plasmid coded antigen called virulence marker antigen (VMA). Manifestations include ulceration of bowel, dysentery (resembling shigellosis). Diagnosis: Detection of VMA by ELISA. HeLa cell invasion assay. Sereny test

questions.text: Diarrhoea in vibrio cholera is due to disruption of which of the following:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Zonula occludens Tight junctions, also known as occluding junctions or zonulae occludentes. They are multiprotein junctional complexes. Function: to prevent leakage of transported solutes and water and seals the paracellular pathway. Hemidesmosomes are very small stud-like structures found in keratinocytes of the epidermis of skin that attach to the extracellular matrix. Hemidesmosomes can be categorized into two types based on their protein constituents. Type 1 hemidesmosomes are found in stratified and pseudo-stratified epithelium. Desmosome , also known as a macula adherens , is a cell structure specialized for cell-to-cell adhesion. A type of junctional complex, they are localized spot-like adhesions randomly arranged on the lateral sides of plasma membranes.

Highyeild:

Pathogenesis: Adhesion and colonization: adhesion to the intestinal epithelium which is facilitated by a special type IV fimbria called toxin coregulated pilus (TCP). It is so named because the synthesis of TCP, cholera toxin and several other virulence factors are coregulated by a single gene called ToxR. Cholera toxin (CT): Once established in the human small intestine, the organism produces a powerful enterotoxin called cholera toxin. It resembles heat-labile toxin (LT) of E. coli in its structure and function, but it is more potent. Zona occludens toxin: It disrupts the tight junctions between mucosal cells.

questions.text: Galactomannan in serum is seen in: Invasive aspergillosis Systemic candidiasis Mucormycosis Cryptococcosis Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1 only Detection of galactomannan in blood is used to diagnose invasive aspergillosis infections in humans. Galactomannans are polysaccharides consisting of a mannose backbone with galactose side groups (more specifically, a (1-4)-linked beta-D-mannopyranose backbone with branch points from their 6-positions linked to alpha-D-galactose, (i.e. 1-6-linked alpha-D-galactopyranose). Galactomannan is a component of the cell wall of Aspergillus and is released during growth.

questions.text: A patient presented with meningitis with a history of fever for 4 days and erythematous rashes on the chest. There was no history of travel and tick bite. His CSF findings showed increased protein, normal glucose, mild lymphocytosis, and few RBCs. Which of the following is the most likely organism to cause this Image?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Enterovirus This is a case of aseptic meningitis. Meningitis with normal glucose, increased protein, and mild lymphocytosis is suggestive of viral meningitis, most probably by an Enterovirus. Coxsackieviruses are typical enteroviruses. Two groups of Coxsackie viruses A and B, are known. Aseptic meningitis may be caused by a majority of group A and all group B viruses. A maculopapular rash may be present. The disease can also occur as epidemics. The most common cause of aseptic meningitis is by viral infection. CSF findings in Viral meningitis: A mild increase in CSF protein/pressure Normal glucose Mild increase in lymphocytes in CSF.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. (Strep. Pneumoniae) and Option B (Meningococci) cause bacterial meningitis which is not in accordance with the CSF findings. Hence, ruled out. Strep pneumoniae: Gram positive cocci. Lanceolate [flame shaped]. Draughtsman/carom coin like colonies on culture. Capsulated Made of polysaccharide. Demonstrated by Quellung reaction. LAB DIAGNOSIS: CSF analysis: Biochemistry for Proteins & Sugars. Culture. THAYER MARTIN MEDIA Most dreadful complication → WATER HOUSE FRIDERICHSEN SYNDROME West Nile virus: It is a single-stranded RNA virus. Family Flaviviridae. Transmitted by mosquitoes, mostly species of Culex, but can be transferred by blood transfusions, breastfeeding, and through the placenta. It causes asymptomatic disease in 80% of those infected, but 20% develop West Nile fever, and less than 1% develop West Nile neurological disease (WNND), which is more likely to occur in individuals older than 60 years of age. There is no history of travel in the question. Hence, ruled out. Diseases caused by Enterovirus: Enterovirus 68: Pneumonia. Enterovirus 70: Acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis. Enterovirus 71: Pulmonary edema, herpangina, aseptic meningitis, and hand-foot-and mouth disease. Enterovirus 70, 71: Paralysis and encephalitis. Enteroviral meningitis primarily occurs in young children.

questions.text: Pneumonia due to a gram-negative pleomorphic bacilli growing on chocolate agar which is catalase and oxidase – positive is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

H. influenzae influenzae is a Gram negative pleomorphic bacilli mostly cultured on chocolate agar. Other organisms in the questions are not cultured on chocolate agar.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. PSEUDOMONAS Gram negative bacilli. Catalase +ve. Oxidase +ve. Best selective media → Cetrimide Agar Pigmentation is seen on culture: Pyoverdin → Green. Pyocyanin → Blue. Pyorubrin → Red. Pyomelanin → Brown Black. Option: B. coli: Gram negative bacilli. Catalase +ve. Oxidase +ve. Culture: MacConkey agar: lactose fermenting colonies. Option: C. Actinomyces: Filamentous organism. An anaerobe, mostly non-acid fast. Mostly not cultured. Oral actinomycosis has a triad of: Sinus. Swelling. Sulphur granules. Option: D. influenzae : Gram negative pleomorphic bacilli. Catalase +ve. Oxidase +ve.

questions.text: Which protein is present is the HPV vaccine?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

L1 The HPV vaccines are based on hollow virus-like particles (VLPs) assembled from recombinant HPV coat proteins. The natural virus capsid is composed of two proteins, L1 and L2, but vaccines only contain L1. Gardasil contains inactive L1 proteins from four different HPV strains: 6, 11, 16, and 18, synthesized in the yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae. Each vaccine dose contains: 225 µg of aluminum, 9.56 mg of sodium chloride, 0.78 mg of L-histidine, 50 µg of polysorbate 80, 35 µg of sodium borate, and water. The combination of ingredients totals 0.5 mL. HPV types 16 and 18 cause about 70% of all cervical cancer. Gardasil also targets HPV types 6 and 11, which together cause about 90 percent of all cases of genital warts.

Extraedge:

Name Gardasil Cervarix Manufacturer Merck Frosst Canada Ltd. GlaxoSmithKline Inc. Type Prophylactic vaccine con- sisting of virus-like par- ticles containing L1 capsid proteins Prophylactic vaccine con- sisting of virus-like par- ticles containing L1 capsid proteins Antigens Quadrivalent vaccine: HPV types 6,11,16 and 18 Bivalent vaccine: HPV types 16 and 18 Dose 0.5 mL intramuscular injec- tion at 0, 2 and 6 months 0.5 mL intramuscular injec- tion at 0, 1 and 6 months Approval Approved for sale Not yet available

questions.text: A 30 year old patient presents with urethral discharge. The gram stain Image is given below. What could be the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Neisseria gonorrhea Gram-stain of gonococcal urethritis is shown in the given Image . It causes the sexually transmitted genitourinary infection gonorrhea as well as other forms of gonococcal disease including disseminated gonococcemia, septic arthritis, and gonococcal ophthalmia neonatorum. It is oxidase positive and aerobic, and it survives within neutrophils. Culturing it requires carbon dioxide supplementation and enriched agar (chocolate agar) with various antimicrobials (Thayer-Martin). It exhibits antigenic variation through recombination of its pili and surface proteins that interact with the immune system. Sexual transmission is possible through vaginal, anal, or oral sex. Sexual transmission may be prevented through the use of barrier protection. Perinatal transmission may occur during childbirth, and may be prevented by antibiotic treatment of the mother before birth and the application of antibiotic eye gel on the eyes of the newborn. After an episode of gonococcal infection, infected persons do not develop immunity to future infections. Reinfection is possible due to N. gonorrhoeae's ability to evade the immune system by varying its surface proteins.

Extraedge:

Chlamydia trachomatis infection may manifest in various ways, including: trachoma, lymphogranuloma venereum, nongonococcal urethritis, cervicitis, salpingitis, pelvic inflammatory disease. Trichomonas vaginalis Gardnerella vaginalis

questions.text: Identify the parasite shown in the Image -
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ascaris lumbricoides The given image shows the roundworm Ascaris lumbricoides. It is the most common of human helminths and is distributed worldwide. Adult worms live in the small intestine (85% in jejunum and 15% in ileum). The roundworm Ascaris lumbricoides is the largest nematode parasite in the human intestine. The adult worms are large cylindrical worms, with tapering ends. The anterior end is more pointed than the posterior Man is the natural host for this organism. There is no intermediate host. Mode of transmission: Infection occurs when the egg containing the infective rhabditiform larva is swallowed. It occurs through food or water contaminated with night soil or human feces containing eggs of ascaris.

questions.text: Match the following with their organs of locomotion (Column (A) with Column – (B)- Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A-3, B-2, C-1, D-4

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: Toxoplasma relies on its actin cytoskeleton to glide and enter its host cell. Toxoplasma gondii, the causative agent of toxoplasmosis, is an obligate intracellular protozoan parasite that infects hepatocytes. Transmission: with cats faeces. Infective forms of Toxoplasma gondii: Tachyzoites Bradyzoites Sporulated oocyst. Option: B . Balantidium coli is a large ciliated protozoan (50-130 um) and width 20-70 um). It inhabits the large intestine of man and causes ciliate dysentery. Infective stage: binucleate cyst; spherical, ellipsoid, 50-75mm, double layered cyst wall. The invasive form is the trophozoite. Option: C. Trichomonas: Flagellum There is only one stage in the life cycle of Trichomonas, trophozoite. vaginalis inhabits the lower genital tract of females and the urethra and prostate of males. Men : asymptomatic but can transmit the infection sexually. Women: manifests with malodorous vaginal discharge (often yellow), vulvar erythema ("strawberry cervix") (Refer to the Image below) and itching, dysuria or urinary frequency. Treatment: All sexual partners must be treated concurrently (Metronidazole). Option: D. Balamuthia is a free living amoeba having pseudopodia. Neuro parasite.

questions.text: Match the following parasites with their intermediate hosts (Column – (A) with Column – (B)- Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A3, B2, C4, D1 Diphyllobothrium Latum: Definitive host: Man. Intermediate host: 1st intermediate host: Crustacean/ cyclops. 2nd intermediate host: Fresh water fish.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option:B. Paragonimus westermani First intermediate host- snail. 2nd intermediate host - crab/ cray fish. In crab metacercariae larva which is cyst like stage is seen. It causes Red Brown sputum or endemic hemoptysis. Option: C. Brugia malayi: Nocturnal strains: Transmitted from Man-Man by bite of Mansonia. Sub periodic strains: Transmitted from monkey (Zoonotic): by Mansonia. Diagnosis: Microfilaria is differentiated from that of W. bancroftian by pointed tail tip, Nuclei column darkly stained, large, coarse, overlapping, extended till the tail tip. Head end of microfilaria - Sheathed, cephalic space (2:1), darkly stained large coarse overlapping nuclei. Tail end of microfilaria – 4-5 nuclei in the tail region and 2 widely spaced nuclei in tail tip . Option: D. Fasciola Hepatica - Sheep Liver Fluke 1st intermediate host : snail. 2nd intermediate host : aquatic vegetation. Mode of transmission: Ingestion of aquatic plant contaminated with encysted metacercaria.
